title: 115_hr1574
content: The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" is a legislation that aims to provide viewpoint protection in communications. It amends Title I of the Communications Act of 1934 to include a new section on viewpoint protection. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. It also prevents the Commission from imposing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. It also prevents the Commission from imposing conditions on viewpoints in transaction reviews, except for violations of specific laws. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content, including violations of specific laws such as sections 1304, 1343, and 1464 of title 18, United States Code. It also covers violations or conduct under sections 312(a)(7), 315, or 317 of the Act, and any public interest obligations outlined in the Act. The "Protecting Dissenting Viewpoints and Voices Act of 2017" prohibits the Commission from taking action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content, including violations of specific laws and public interest obligations. The President is also restricted from directing agencies to retaliate against individuals based on their viewpoints on public importance issues. The President is prohibited from directing agencies to take action against individuals based on their viewpoints on public issues in broadcast content. This includes not retaliating against individuals for their viewpoints or placing conditions on approvals based on viewpoints. The President cannot direct agencies to take action or impose conditions on approvals based on public viewpoints in broadcast content. This does not affect the President's authority to act on violations of specific laws. The agency cannot impose conditions on approvals based on public viewpoints in broadcast content related to specific violations of certain laws. The agency cannot impose conditions on broadcast content related to specific violations of laws, including incitement under the First Amendment or duties of the President. The term "agency" is defined as in section 551 of the law. The term "agency" is defined as in section 551 of title 5, United States Code.
